title: Tree Definition
content:
A **tree** is a connected acyclic graph.

Equivalently: a connected graph with n vertices and n-1 edges, or a graph where any two vertices have a unique path between them.

title: Bipartite with Parts
content:
A graph is **bipartite with parts A and B** if:
- A and B are disjoint
- A ∪ B = all vertices
- Every edge goes between A and B

All trees are bipartite!

title: BipartiteTree Structure
content:
A `BipartiteTree k` is a tree with a specific bipartition:
- Part A has exactly k vertices
- Part B has exactly 2k vertices
- Total: 3k vertices

This is the class of trees Erdős conjectured has R(T) = 4k - 1.

title: Edge 2-Coloring
content:
An **edge 2-coloring** assigns true or false (red or blue) to each edge.

We use `Sym2 V → Bool` where Sym2 V represents unordered pairs.

title: Monochromatic Copy
content:
A graph H appears **monochromatically** in color c if there's an injective map f: V(H) → V(G) such that:
- f preserves edges: H.Adj u v → G.Adj (f u) (f v)
- All images have color c

This is the structure Ramsey numbers guarantee.

title: Ramsey Number R(H)
content:
**R(H)** is the minimum n such that every 2-coloring of K_n contains a monochromatic copy of H.

For any graph H, R(H) exists and is finite (Ramsey's theorem).

title: Star Graph S_n
content:
The **star graph S_n** has:
- One center vertex (index 0)
- n leaf vertices (indices 1..n)
- Edges only between center and leaves

R(S_n) = 2n - 1 (known result).

title: Double Star
content:
The **double star** for parameter k:
- First star S_k: center at 0, leaves at 1..k
- Second star S_{2k}: center at k+1, leaves at k+2..3k+1
- One edge connecting the two centers

This tree has 3k + 2 vertices and is the counterexample!

title: Erdős's Conjecture
content:
**The Original Conjecture:**

For every k ≥ 1 and every bipartite (k, 2k) tree T:

R(T) = 4k - 1

This would give an exact formula for a large class of trees.

title: Norin-Sun-Zhao Counterexample
content:
**The Conjecture is FALSE!**

Norin, Sun, and Zhao found a bipartite (k, 2k) tree T with R(T) > 4k - 1.

The counterexample is the double star.

title: Double Star Lower Bound
content:
**Norin-Sun-Zhao Bound:**

R(double star) ≥ (4.2 - o(1))k

Since 4.2k > 4k - 1 for large k, this disproves the conjecture.

title: The Constant 4.2
content:
The Norin-Sun-Zhao constant is approximately **4.2**.

For any ε > 0 and large enough k:

R(double star) ≥ (4.2 - ε) · k

title: Flag Algebra Upper Bound
content:
**Flag Algebra Method:**

R(T) ≤ (4.21526 + o(1))k for all bipartite (k, 2k) trees.

Flag algebras use semidefinite programming to prove graph limits. The bound 4.21526 is computed, not proved by hand.

title: Bounds Gap
content:
**Tight Bounds:**

4.21526 - 4.2 < 0.02

The true constant is known to within 0.02!

title: Path Graph
content:
The **path graph P_n** is the simplest tree: n vertices in a line.

P_n is bipartite with parts of size ⌈n/2⌉ and ⌊n/2⌋.

R(P_n) = n for n ≥ 2.

title: Broom Graph
content:
A **broom** is a path with a star attached at one end:
- Path of length pathLen
- Star with starSize leaves at the end

Brooms are 'nice' trees that still satisfy R(T) = 4k - 1.

title: Bounded Degree Case
content:
**Special Case: Bounded Degree**

For any fixed maximum degree Δ, trees with max degree ≤ Δ satisfy R(T) = 4k - 1.

The counterexample needs unbounded degree (star centers have degree k and 2k).

title: General Lower Bound
content:
**Lower Bound Always Holds:**

R(T) ≥ 4k - 1 for ALL bipartite (k, 2k) trees.

The conjecture fails only as an upper bound. No tree can have R(T) < 4k - 1.

title: Lower Bound Construction
content:
**Construction for R(T) ≥ 4k - 1:**

2-color K_{4k-2} using the bipartite structure K_{2k-1, 2k-1}:
- Red edges within each part
- Blue edges between parts

Neither color contains T (too few vertices in each 'side').

title: Chvátal-Harary Bound
content:
**General Tree Bound (Chvátal-Harary):**

For any tree T on n vertices: R(T) ≤ 2n - 2.

This is a universal upper bound for all trees.

title: Burr-Erdős Formula
content:
**Burr-Erdős Conjecture:**

For 'nice' graphs H with chromatic number χ:

R(H) = (χ - 1)(|H| - 1) + 1

For trees (χ = 2), this gives R(T) = |T|, which is too small. The 4k - 1 formula is a refinement for the (k, 2k) case.

title: Main Result
content:
**Erdős Problem #549: SOLVED (Disproved)**

The conjecture R(T) = 4k - 1 for bipartite (k, 2k) trees is FALSE.

Counterexample: The double star has R ≥ 4.2k.

Best bounds: 4.2k ≤ R(double star) ≤ 4.21526k.
